medium: Red, yellow, and blue acrylic yarn
creditline: Museum purchase, Fowler McCormick, Class of 1921, Fund
creditlinerepro: © Estate of Fred Sandback, Courtesy of Rhona Hoffman Gallery

makers.displaydate: 1943–2003; born Bronxville, NY; active New York, NY
makers.displaymaker: Fred Sandback, 1943–2003; born Bronxville, NY; active New York, NY

texts.textentryhtml: Estate of Fred Sandback, Rindge, New Hampshire, consigned; to [Barbara Krakow Gallery, Boston, Massachusetts], sold; to Princeton University Art Museum, 2006.
texts.remarks: as per info and certificate of authenticity in curatorial file. AP.

texts.textentryhtml: In this work, three lengths of primary-colored acrylic yarn are tightly secured to the ceiling and floor in order to form the outline of a triangle. By delineating a triangular plane in space, Untitled (Triangle) affects the visitor’s experience of moving through the gallery, intervening in what Sandback called “pedestrian space.” The piece has been installed according to his instructions, which call for the triangle to be the height of the ceiling, with a base 2.94 times that measurement. By using yarn, Sandback created a sculpture that varies in size depending on the height of the space in which it is installed, while maintaining a constant scale in relation to the room’s dimensions.

bibliography.boilertext: Carl Haenlein, Ahrens Carsten and Fred Sandback. Fred Sandback: diagonal constructions/broken lines: skulpturen und zeichnungen, (Hannover: Kestner-Gesellschaft, 1987).
bibliography.citation: Carl Haenlein, Ahrens Carsten and Fred Sandback. Fred Sandback: diagonal constructions/broken lines: skulpturen und zeichnungen, (Hannover: Kestner-Gesellschaft, 1987)., p. 29, (color illus.), installation view Kestner-Gesellschaft, Hannover.
